advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT#2 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Here comes Sirius 1 : the micro-computer which has an elephant memory"<br> ...<br> "A new era for computing"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #16</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEWBURRY BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>According to this brochure, Newbury had four models:<br><br> Model M: Main Only<br> Model MB: Main and with Batteries and display<br> Model MD: Mains only with display<br> Model MBS: Main and with Batteries and display with special low power consumption. <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.oldcomputers.freeserve.co.uk</b> </p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #6 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The new sale price is $99.95 instead of 149.95 <br><br> Advert said: <br><br> <font color="#666666">The ZX81 represents the latest technology in microelectronics. More than 10,000 are sold every week. In fact, the ZX81 is the best selling personal computer in the world.</font> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NORTHSTAR CARDS</strong></font><br><blockquote>Northstar also designed cards for S100 Bus. These cards were used in the Horizon and were also available separately for competing systems.<br> Cards on the photo are:<br> - 16 KB RAM board ($459 assembled)<br> - Micro Disk System (card & interface) to connect Shugart FDD ($799)<br> - Z80A processor board ($259 without EPROM option, $330 with)<br> - Hardware floating point card ($359). </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> QUASAR AD (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The 8 KB quasar system with the 4 color plotter/printer interface.<br><br> The small picture shows a complete system with memory expansion, modem and video interfaces.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. (1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In U.K., at 1986 Christmas period, the 1040 STF was sold £799 + VAT for the 12" monochrome version, and £999 + VAT for the 14" colour version.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPAN ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>It's an advert for both the YIS-503 and YIS-303 which were quite similar except for the keyboard and the memory size...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a German advertisement for the BIT-60 and BIT-90 models. Atari VCS-2600 cartridges are scattered in front of the BIT-60 to show that the it is really compatible with the VCS-2600 ! But strangely enough, there is no picture displayed on the TV. Were these models really working ? ;-)</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN LEAFLET #4</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT #2 (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">What in the name of Adam do people do with Apple computers?<br> You tell us.<br> In a thousand of words or less.<br> If your story is original and intriguing enough, you can win a one-week trip to Hawaii. Which is the closest we could come to paradise.</font><br><br> Unfortunately, the contest ended March 31, 1980... </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ORANGE+ US AD. (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">thanks to <a href="http://www.textfiles.com" target="_blank">www.textfiles.com</a> for this scan</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1977 ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>The advert said : <br><br> Waiting for you, all the incredible performance and power of the IMSAI 8080. And at a price you would normally pay for a home music system : $699 in kit, $931 assembled...<br><br> <b>WORLS OF USES : </b>The IMSAI 8080 is a superbly engineered, putting litterally hundreds of applications and uses at your fingertype...<br><br> <b>GROWS WITH YOU : </b>The IMSAI 8080 is designed for many years of pleasure. With its open-chassis engineering, you can expand your system by adding peripherals and interfaces. The 22 slots and 28 amperes power supply mean that you can plug-in todays's plus tomorrow's modules. Right now, you can add a module for displaying color graphics and characters on TV, a ready-to-use keyboard, a cassette tape recorder, small and large printers...<br><br> <b>EASY TO PROGRAM : </b>With our BASIC language, you can operate the IMSAI 8080 quickly and easily. Thechnically knowledgeable ? Use our assembly language to develop sophisticated and unique software.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"At the fingertip of the mouse..." <br><br> "... 16/32 bits technology"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> M5 PRO & M5 JR JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.pugly.juice.or.jp/pugly/oldpc/" target="_blank">Pugly</a> for this picture!</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>French advert for correspondance courses using MPF-1 computers.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LAST SALES</strong></font><br><blockquote>In July 1985, California Digital sold the Tano at $99. The price would decrease down to $35 while stock last.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Before being told about it, come hear it yourself."</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> EQUIPED FOR COMPETITION</strong></font><br><blockquote>French advert (december 1984)</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 6000 MODEL</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> WE HAVE A NEW APPROACH TO DISTRIBUTED PROCESSING THAT WORKS <br><br> Already implemented are electronic mail, word processing, complete cost accounting with inventory control and more. The secret is a new technology called Functionally Structured Distribution (FSD). At last, a system to organize and manage distributed processing applications that is really up and running. FSD technology is especially applicable to installa­tions that require:<br> • Unlimited expandability supporting extremely large data bases and terminals in many cities.<br> • User-friendly software easily programmed in high level languages (COBOL, FORTRAN, and BASIC)<br> • System reliability (due to distributed hardware) while maintaining multiple levels of data security.<br> • Compatibility with existing mainframes and networks (including the Bell System). <br><br> We are presently installing Billings 6000 Computer Systems which take full advantage of distributed processing utilizing FSD technology. The 6000 Computer supports multiple hard disk drives with capacities of up to 64 Mbytes (formatted), streaming tapes for backup, auto-dial modems (2400 baud synchronous) for communications, and flexible disk drives for smaller installations.</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

computer.description:
This japanese computer seems quite powerful. The main board is located into the main case, under the monitor.
Inside this main case there are 6 expansion slots which is quite enough ! Thus a lot of expansion boards were available (disk, printers, 8088, Z80 boards, etc).
An interesting feature is that there's a little trap-door on the keyboard which reveals some cool control switches : a power switch, a text mode switch (80 / 40 columns), a reset button and volume control knob. Quite useful !
computer.keyboard: QWERTY full-stroke keyboard, separated numeric keypad, 5 function keys
computer.name: MB-6890 / Basic Master Level 3
computer.peripherals: Tape-recorder, printer interface board, light-pen, Chinese character ROM board, 8088 CPU board, Disk Interface board, Z80 CPU board, RAM expansion boards

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> THE KEYBOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.japan-net.ne.jp/~a-ueda/oldcom/">Ueda's Page</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
